panels.description: Request success rate. 99.5% or higher is considered normal (green); below 98% is considered critical (red). Only normally completed requests with finished_reason='stop' are counted as successful.
panels.title: Success Rate

panels.description: Number of requests currently being processed (Running) plus waiting (Waiting). A sharp increase indicates a traffic surge.
panels.title: Active Requests

panels.description: Scheduler efficiency. Running / (Running + Waiting). 100% means all requests are processed immediately. Below 70% indicates overload.

targets.expr: clamp_max((sum(vllm:num_requests_running{namespace="$namespace", service="$service", model_name="$model_name"}) + 0.001) / (sum(vllm:num_requests_running{namespace="$namespace", service="$service", model_name="$model_name"}) + sum(vllm:num_requests_waiting{namespace="$namespace", service="$service", model_name="$model_name"}) + 0.001), 1)

panels.title: System Efficiency

panels.description: Time to first token (P99). A key metric for the initial response latency perceived by users. Under 1 second is ideal.
panels.title: TTFT P99

panels.description: [Critical] Preemption rate. Running requests are interrupted due to insufficient KV cache. Any value above 0 requires immediate investigation. Consider increasing GPU memory or reducing batch size.
panels.title: Preemption Rate

panels.description: Tokens processed per second. Input (Prompt) = input tokens, Output (Generation) = output tokens. Higher throughput indicates better system efficiency.
panels.title: Token Throughput

panels.description: Time the request waited in the queue. The time spent in the waiting state queue. After the LLM inference request arrives at the vLLM server, it may not be processed immediately, but needs to wait for the vLLM scheduler to schedule the prefill and decode.
panels.title: Request Queue Time

panels.description: TTFT (time to first token) vs TPOT (time per token) comparison. A high TTFT indicates a Prefill bottleneck, while a high TPOT indicates a Decode bottleneck.
panels.title: TTFT vs TPOT

panels.description: Ratio of output tokens to input tokens.
panels.title: Token I/O Ratio

panels.description:
Percentage of computation saved by the Prefix Cache. The higher the value, the more Prefill computations the cache skips, saving GPU resources.
(1 − actual computation / total input) × 100.
panels.title: Prefix Cache Savings

panels.description: End to end request latency measured in seconds.
panels.title: E2E Request Latency

panels.description: P50, P90, P95, and P99 TTFT latency in seconds.
panels.title: Time To First Token Latency

panels.description: End-to-end time per token, including queuing, model inference, and system overhead.
panels.title: Request Time Per Output Token Latency

panels.description:
Inter token latency in seconds. 

⚠️ Only applies to text-generation LLMs. Not valid for embedding requests.
panels.title: Inter Token Latency (⚠️For LLM only)
Max Generation Token in Sequence Group

panels.description: Proportion of latency: Prefill (input processing) vs Decode (output generation). A high Prefill ratio indicates a long input prompt, while a high Decode ratio indicates that long output generation is the bottleneck.
panels.title: Inference Stage Breakdown

panels.description: Prompt Tokens processed per second.
panels.title: Token Throughput (Prompt)

panels.description: Generated tokens throughput. Number of tokens produced per second by the model, indicating system workload and efficiency.
panels.title: Token Throughput (Generation)

panels.description:
Distribution of input (prompt) token counts per request.
Darker colors indicate a higher number of requests at that length.
If requests are concentrated in a specific range, consider optimizing for that length.
panels.title: Request Prompt Length Heatmap

panels.description:
Distribution of generated token counts per request. 
Darker colors indicate a higher number of requests at that length.
panels.title: Request Generation Length Heatmap

panels.description:
Represents the percentage of KV Cache memory currently in use by vLLM for storing intermediate attention states. Sustained usage above 80% indicates memory pressure and should be monitored closely.
Usage above 95% significantly increases the risk of request preemption and degraded performance.
panels.title: KV Cache Usage

panels.description: Percentage of reuse of identical system prompts or few-shot examples. Values above 70% indicate efficient cache usage.
panels.title: Prefix Cache Hit Rate

panels.description:
Number of requests by scheduler state: Running (inference in progress)
Waiting (in the queue), and
Swapped (swapped to memory).
A continuous increase in Waiting indicates system overload.
panels.title: Scheduler State

panels.description: Distribution of request completion reasons: stop (normal EOS), length (max length reached), and abort (aborted), where a high abort ratio indicates an issue.
panels.title: Finish Reason Distribution

panels.description: Total vs. successful request throughput, where any gap indicates failed requests and consistent alignment is expected under normal conditions.
panels.title: Throughput vs Success
